definition: drop in price/devalued/to have one's status lowered

to fall/to drop/to lag behind/to lose/to go missing/to reduce/fall (in prices)/to lose (value, weight etc)/to wag/to swing/to turn/to change/to exchange/to swap/to show off/to shed (hair)/(used after certain verbs to express completion, fulfillment, removal etc)
erhua variant of 掉價|掉价[diao4 jia4]

sentences.english: She feels devalued because she knows her husband has had affairs.
sentences.chinese: 她觉得自己掉价了，因为她知道丈夫有了外遇。

sentences.english: The quality of the book is diluted by the bad writing.
sentences.chinese: 那本书的质量因文字拙劣而掉价了。

sentences.english: His prices don't seem to be plummeting with the global recession, either.
sentences.chinese: 在全球经济衰退之际，蔡国强的作品似乎也没有掉价。

sentences.english: To overcome valence rate, accelerating capital have enough to meet need is the problem that urgent need solves.
sentences.chinese: 为克服掉价率，加快资金周转是迫切需要解决的问题。

definition: erhua variant of 掉價|掉价[diao4 jia4]
to lose money instead of being paid (i.e. sb should pay me, but is actually taking my money)
not presentable/shoddy and too embarrassing to show
to fall behind the ranks/to be outdated
see 愛面子|爱面子[ai4 mian4 zi5]
it isn't worth it/not cost-effective/not profitable/too expensive
